messages.text:
is objectid the same as id in Cpython ?
in Cpython ...
```[ins] In [2]: id?                                                                                         
Signature: id(obj, /)
Docstring:
Return the identity of an object.

This is guaranteed to be unique among simultaneously existing objects.
(CPython uses the object's memory address.)
Type:      builtin_function_or_method```

messages.text: How would I go about expanding the following code for any number of vectors (possibly using `Iterators` or `@nloops`)?  My code below shows it working for the first three vectors.

files.name: Untitled
files.title: Untitled
files.preview:
function list_span(u̲::Vector{T}, v̲::Vector{T}, modulo::Int) where T <: Number
	span = Vector{T}[]
	
	for λ in 0:(modulo - 1), γ in 0:(modulo - 1)
		w̲ = mod.(λ*u̲ + γ*v̲, modulo)
files.preview_highlight:
function list_span(u̲::Vector{T}, v̲::Vector{T}, modulo::Int) where T <: Number
	span = Vector{T}[]
	
	for λ in 0:(modulo - 1), γ in 0:(modulo - 1)
		w̲ = mod.(λ*u̲ + γ*v̲, modulo)

messages.text: I have a weird problem with passing a callback function pointer (returned by `@cfunction`) to a shared library. The function pointer is passed to the library via a field of a structure.  I have added a test function to the shared library that calls the callback function stored in the structure.  I can `ccall` this test function from Julia and the Julia callback function gets called as expected without problems, but when it comes time for the library to call the same callback function it segfaults even though the callback function pointer has the same value as when called from the test function.  Any ideas on what could be going wrong or how to debug this?

elements.text: I have a weird problem with passing a callback function pointer (returned by
@cfunction

) to a shared library. The function pointer is passed to the library via a field of a structure.  I have added a test function to the shared library that calls the callback function stored in the structure.  I can
ccall

this test function from Julia and the Julia callback function gets called as expected without problems, but when it comes time for the library to call the same callback function it segfaults even though the callback function pointer has the same value as when called from the test function.  Any ideas on what could be going wrong or how to debug this?

messages.text:
Ok, so I created a macro `@each` that just prints out each line in an iterator:
```macro each(iterator)
    quote
        @info $(sprint(Base.show_unquoted, iterator)) * ":"
        for e in $iterator
            @info "--> $e"
        end
    end
end```
This works well when I run it in the same file:
```x = 1:3
@each x```
results in:
```[ Info: x:
[ Info: --> 1
[ Info: --> 2
[ Info: --> 3```
but  when I do the same in the REPL I get this:
```julia> y = 1:10
1:10

julia> @each y
[ Info: y:
ERROR: UndefVarError: y not defined```
What is happening here?

elements.text: Ok, so I created a macro
@each
that just prints out each line in an iterator:

macro each(iterator)
    quote
        @info $(sprint(Base.show_unquoted, iterator)) * ":"
        for e in $iterator
            @info "--> $e"
        end
    end
end
This works well when I run it in the same file:

x = 1:3
@each x
results in:

[ Info: x:
[ Info: --> 1
[ Info: --> 2
[ Info: --> 3
but  when I do the same in the REPL I get this:

julia> y = 1:10
1:10

julia> @each y
[ Info: y:
ERROR: UndefVarError: y not defined
What is happening here?

messages.text:
Just curious how this is done in Matlab. Seems like depending on what variable you assign the result to you get different function calls.
Is this possible in Julia?
```e = eig(A) returns a column vector containing the eigenvalues of square matrix A.
example
[V,D] = eig(A) returns diagonal matrix D of eigenvalues and matrix V whose columns are the corresponding right eigenvectors, so that A*V = V*D.```
<https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/nargout.html>

attachments.title: Number of function output arguments - MATLAB nargout
attachments.text: This MATLAB function returns the number of function output arguments specified in the call to the currently executing function.

Is this possible in Julia?

e = eig(A) returns a column vector containing the eigenvalues of square matrix A.
example

messages.text:
Hi, I’m just starting out with Julia and ran into a weird issue. I defined a function that can take float values (fp32 or fp64, but strictly no int) as follows
```function elim(A::Array{float},b::Array{float})
    #=
    Function which transforms matrix
    A into upper triangular matrix U
    =#
    n = size(b)[1]
    
    # Pick a pivot row
    for k in 1:n-1
        for i in k+1:n
            if A[i,k] != 0
                lambda = A[i,k]/A[k,k]
                A[i,k+1:n] -= lambda*A[k,k+1:n]
                b[i,:] -= lambda*b[k,:]
            end
        end
    end
    return A, b
end```
Now when I call this function and give inputs as Float32
```A = [[6, -4, 1] [-4, 6, -4] [1, -4, 6]]
b = [[-14, 36, 6] [22, -18, 7]];
A = Float32.(A)
b = Float32.(b);

U, b_t = elim(A,b)
show(stdout, "text/plain", U)
println()
show(stdout, "text/plain", b_t)```
I get an error saying
```MethodError: no method matching elim(::Array{Float32,2}, ::Array{Float32,2})

Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at In[3]:1
 [2] include_string(::Function, ::Module, ::String, ::String) at ./loading.jl:1091```
I get the same error when I input Float64. Is there any way that I can define a function that takes both Float32 and Float64? I don’t want to define two separate functions as it’ll just clutter everything for no reason.

elements.text: Hi, I’m just starting out with Julia and ran into a weird issue. I defined a function that can take float values (fp32 or fp64, but strictly no int) as follows

function elim(A::Array{float},b::Array{float})
    #=
    Function which transforms matrix
    A into upper triangular matrix U
    =#
    n = size(b)[1]
    
    # Pick a pivot row
    for k in 1:n-1
        for i in k+1:n
            if A[i,k] != 0
                lambda = A[i,k]/A[k,k]
                A[i,k+1:n] -= lambda*A[k,k+1:n]
                b[i,:] -= lambda*b[k,:]
            end
        end
    end
    return A, b
end
Now when I call this function and give inputs as Float32

A = [[6, -4, 1] [-4, 6, -4] [1, -4, 6]]
b = [[-14, 36, 6] [22, -18, 7]];
A = Float32.(A)
b = Float32.(b);

U, b_t = elim(A,b)
show(stdout, "text/plain", U)
println()
show(stdout, "text/plain", b_t)
I get an error saying

MethodError: no method matching elim(::Array{Float32,2}, ::Array{Float32,2})

Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at In[3]:1
 [2] include_string(::Function, ::Module, ::String, ::String) at ./loading.jl:1091

I get the same error when I input Float64. Is there any way that I can define a function that takes both Float32 and Float64? I don’t want to define two separate functions as it’ll just clutter everything for no reason.

messages.text:
I wrote a loop with a `cis` call on complex types (see code pasted below), and I was hoping to get this to vectorize appropriately. However, looking at the `@code_llvm` output, it does not appear to vectorize, so I just wanted to see if anyone could help me out understanding if I should even expect this loop to vectorize, or how I might rewrite it in a way that will. I am not particularly experienced in reading the `@code_llvm` output, so it _is_ possible that the code does vectorize, although looking at runtimes for varying array sizes -- as done in the pasted code -- would indicate that it is not. Thanks for any help!

```function Heisenberg!(ρₕ, ρ, ω, τ)
    for i in eachindex(ρ, ρₕ, ω)
        @inbounds ρₕ[i] = ρ[i] * cis(ω[i] * τ)
    end
    return nothing
end

n = 1
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
8.399 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

n = 2
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
21.542 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

n = 12
dρ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ρ₀ = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
ω = ComplexF32.(rand(n,n))
τ = 1.0f0
@btime Heisenberg!($dρ, $ρ₀, $ω, $τ)
831.313 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```

messages.text:
Hi guys, first Merry Christmas for everyone who celebrate this date. Second, I have quite an intricate problem here. I'm trying to use a C library in my Julia code. I have a structure (say S) in the Julia side where I have an array of pointers (say S.array). In the Julia side I initalize S.array[i] to be C_NULL for every i. The C code allocates memory for the entries in the S.array, so after calling the C code, S.array[0], for example, is populated. The problem is that I'm getting an error when trying to do unsafe_load(S.array[1]) (changed from 0 to 1 because of Julia's index system). Debugging the code I discovered the following:
• The address of S.array is the same, both on Julia and C side.
• The address of S.array[0] in C is different than S.array[1] in Julia.
I already tried doing unsafe_wrap on S.array, but same error happens. I'm not sure how to proceed here. Any help is greatly appreciated. Thanks!

elements.text: Hi guys, first Merry Christmas for everyone who celebrate this date. Second, I have quite an intricate problem here. I'm trying to use a C library in my Julia code. I have a structure (say S) in the Julia side where I have an array of pointers (say S.array). In the Julia side I initalize S.array[i] to be C_NULL for every i. The C code allocates memory for the entries in the S.array, so after calling the C code, S.array[0], for example, is populated. The problem is that I'm getting an error when trying to do unsafe_load(S.array[1]) (changed from 0 to 1 because of Julia's index system). Debugging the code I discovered the following:
The address of S.array is the same, both on Julia and C side.
The address of S.array[0] in C is different than S.array[1] in Julia.
I already tried doing unsafe_wrap on S.array, but same error happens. I'm not sure how to proceed here. Any help is greatly appreciated. Thanks!

messages.text:
I am writing a macro which takes a method expression `f(x) = ...`, decomposes it using `MacroTools.splitdef`, changes some stuff, and then tries to reassemble this into a an invocation of the `@generated` macro. To do so, I replace the original method body by
```quote
    $init
    $(Meta.quot(body))
end```
I.e. perform some initialization, then return the original body in quoted form (actually I slightly transformed `body`, but that shouldn't matter.

Here is my problem: the quoted code returned by the macro is put through a `gensym` transformation. In particular this replaces `x` by something like `var"#154#x"` -- except it doesn't do that in the now quoted part.
I can solve this by using `esc` everywhere to avoid the `gensym` transformation, but I wonder if I can do the reverse: can I somehow transform the `body` to use the same replacement syms as Julia will apply to the rest of the code?

messages.text:
I implemented the `pascals triangle` function:
```function triangle(n)
    n < 0 && return throw(DomainError(""))
    ans = Vector{Vector{Int64}}()
    row = Vector{Int64}()
    n == 0 && return ans
    return generate(n, row, ans)
end

function generate(n_row::Int64, row::Vector{Int64}, ans::Vector{Vector{Int64}})
    if n_row == 1
        push!(row, 1)
        tmp = Vector{Int64}()
        push!(tmp, 1)
        push!(ans, tmp)
        return ans
    end
    generate(n_row - 1, row, ans)
    if length(row) == 1
        push!(row, 1)
    else
        for i in 1:length(row)-1
            row[i] += row[i+1]
        end
        pushfirst!(row, 1)
    end
    tmp = Vector{Int64}()
    map(row[1:end]) do x
        push!(tmp, x)
    end
    push!(ans, tmp)
    return ans
end```
in `generate` function, I have to use the `tmp` at `push!(ans, tmp)` because The value of `ans` will change with the value of `row`

Is it possible passing arguments by value instead of by reference/call-by-sharing?

elements.text: I implemented the
pascals triangle
function:

function triangle(n)
    n < 0 && return throw(DomainError(""))
    ans = Vector{Vector{Int64}}()
    row = Vector{Int64}()
    n == 0 && return ans
    return generate(n, row, ans)
end

function generate(n_row::Int64, row::Vector{Int64}, ans::Vector{Vector{Int64}})
    if n_row == 1
        push!(row, 1)
        tmp = Vector{Int64}()
        push!(tmp, 1)
        push!(ans, tmp)
        return ans
    end
    generate(n_row - 1, row, ans)
    if length(row) == 1
        push!(row, 1)
    else
        for i in 1:length(row)-1
            row[i] += row[i+1]
        end
        pushfirst!(row, 1)
    end
    tmp = Vector{Int64}()
    map(row[1:end]) do x
        push!(tmp, x)
    end
    push!(ans, tmp)
    return ans
end
in
generate
function, I have to use the
tmp
at
push!(ans, tmp)
because The value of
ans
will change with the value of
row
Is it possible passing arguments by value instead of by reference/call-by-sharing?

  $key1 = $val1
  $key2 = $val2
  ...
end```

```    init = quote end
    for x in symdict
        init = quote $init ; $(x[1]) = $(x[2]) end
    end
    init = MacroTools.flatten(init)```

messages.text:
Or I guess based on this from the manual
```Package directories provide a simpler kind of environment without the ability to handle name collisions. In a package directory, the set of top-level packages is the set of subdirectories that "look like" packages. A package X is exists in a package directory if the directory contains one of the following "entry point" files:

X.jl
X/src/X.jl
X.jl/src/X.jl```
I really just want to know "how do you make a package directory"?

messages.text:
Is it ever possible to `using` packages which are not explicitly marked as dependencies in a `Project.toml`? I'm imagining a single directory that contains files `A.jl`, `B.jl`, etc, each defining a module `A`, `B`, etc. It'd be nice if, for interactive use, one could create such a file and then, with that directory as the working directory, `using A`. But instead it seems necessary to:
• initialize a git repo for each module `A`, `B`, etc.
• modify the main `Project.toml` by `]dev /path/to/A` etc
which is a headache for sure. `Pkg` is so well designed I imagine there has to be a better way, but I've never been able to figure it out.

The manual seems to describe something like this in the code loading section: <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/code-loading/#Environments>, i.e. a package directory. But I've never been able to get the behavior described there to work, never been able to get `using A` to load a module `A` which is not explicitly marked in the `Project.toml`

messages.text:
When dealing with composed composite types, e.g.
```struct Point; x; y; z; end

struct Line; r1 :: Point; r2 :: Point; end```
I just end up writing longer code by defining these "accessor" functions: `x(p :: Point) = p.x, r1(line :: Line) = line.r1`, and similarly for the others. I think defining those functions is something that could definitely be automated, like how Haskell deals with data types. Is there something similar in Julia? Defining nested accessors by something like  `r1_x(line :: Line) = (x ∘ r1)(line)` also ends up in longer code.

elements.text: When dealing with composed composite types, e.g.

struct Point; x; y; z; end

struct Line; r1 :: Point; r2 :: Point; end
I just end up writing longer code by defining these "accessor" functions:
x(p :: Point) = p.x, r1(line :: Line) = line.r1

, and similarly for the others. I think defining those functions is something that could definitely be automated, like how Haskell deals with data types. Is there something similar in Julia? Defining nested accessors by something like
r1_x(line :: Line) = (x ∘ r1)(line)
also ends up in longer code.

messages.text:
Is there a way to deal with a missing method other than using try/catch? I'd like to avoid exception handling but do the equivalent of
```try
    lmul!(A, B)
catch
    B = A * B  # OK, we'll accept the allocation
end```
Adding a fallback method to `lmul!` would work but is type piracy. A bunch of explicit `(A, B) isa Tuple{...}` seems like poor design (e.g. if another package adds methods to `lmul!`), and the number of methods on `lmul!` is way too high for this anyway.

elements.text: Is there a way to deal with a missing method other than using try/catch? I'd like to avoid exception handling but do the equivalent of

    lmul!(A, B)
catch

end
Adding a fallback method to
lmul!
would work but is type piracy. A bunch of explicit
(A, B) isa Tuple{...}
seems like poor design (e.g. if another package adds methods to
lmul!
), and the number of methods on
lmul!
is way too high for this anyway.

messages.text: Right, but naive Boyer-More ignores that you can stop trying to match if the first letter doesn't match. Same goes for SIMD support - You could reproduce short strings and compare e.g. 4 positions at the same time, which will probably be faster than naive Boyer-Moore.

elements.text: Right, but naive Boyer-More ignores that you can stop trying to match if the first letter doesn't match. Same goes for SIMD support - You could reproduce short strings and compare e.g. 4 positions at the same time, which will probably be faster than naive Boyer-Moore.
